commentBody:
My five favorite original clues from last week
(in order of appearance):

1. Break down while studying?  (7)(8)
2. Things made by toddlers and directors  (6)
3. Free spirits?  (8)
4. Setting for a landscape  (6)
5. New Yorkie, say  (3)


REVERSE ENGINEER
SCENES
EXORCISE
CANVAS
PUP

I know it's Monday, but do we really have to put up with "Opposite of WNW" as a clue for ESE? üôÑ 
There are lots of "suffix for ..." clues that are Monday easy, but at least take a tiny bit of thought. 

Right up there on the lazy scale with the 'The number of this clue' clues that we sometimes see. üßê

Charming Monday! The different applications of the ROLE REVERSAL seemed fresh to me, I smiled at SEEYOUNEVER, and I learned a new word (ASADO) and a new artist (ALISON Beichdel) and all in 7 min or less, what more can you ask from a Monday?
Welcome to the column Natan Last. I already plugged his wonderful book reviewing the history and ongoing cultural significance of crosswords, ‚ÄúAcross the Universe‚Äù a couple weeks ago, but I‚Äôll take the opportunity to plug it again, it‚Äôs a great read for any crossword lover.

A very cool puzzle!  How to lead the newbies through some possibly difficult fills with get-able crosses, and ones that were not dorky!  This is a tall order for any day, and especially for a Monday. I was entertained from start to finish.

Thank you, Hannah!! ‚ù§Ô∏è

Feb 23 crossword 20 across clue:  hole to put a lace through
your answer is "eyelet," but I'm pretty sure, it is "aglet."
Eyelet is a type of clothing trim, generally.
35-Down is a wrong clue. "Mass ___ (Boston thoroughfare)" has no abbreviation indicator, but the answer is an abbreviation. Took me hours to figure that one out.
Enjoyable puzzle.

LOBSTAH TRAP (sic) reminds me of a gripe I thought you people might have opinions on.

Some of us are getting a ‚ÄúNor‚Äô Easter‚Äù (sic) now, and this term has always bugged me. Is it meant to capture the way a New Englander would say it? Because, no, if I say it in a Maine accent, it is ‚ÄúNo‚Äôth Eastah‚Äù.
What is the ‚ÄúNor‚Äù doing there?

I think it is an example of fakELORe, to use today‚Äôs theme!
"Unless someone like you cares a whole awful lot, nothing is going to get better. It‚Äôs not."
Nice and easy Monday to start the work week, and my first ever sub-three minute puzzle :)
‚ÄúPlease like and subscribe‚Äù on YouTube videos is called BEGGING, and it‚Äôs insufferable.
I wonder if at any point during my solve ALISON and Rita had a conversation about something other than a man.

Nice enjoyable Monday - good level, fine clues, decent theme that was helpful to fill in some squares, not too many obscurities (for me). Happy camper here!
Thanks Hannah!

Thank you to the editors for not circling or shading ELOR. It's nice not to have the theme given away before even getting a chance to think about it. 

Overall a satisfying puzzle to start the week. Some good debut entries.

This Monday puzzle felt "very clean" (if you've seen "A Hard Day's Night," you would understand how apt this is for the puzzle), in the sense that the fill wasn't overly reliant on that crosswordese garbage. A lot of the fill felt very satisfying to put in, really. The theme was also cute, with the "ELOR" in each one. Not perfect, but definitely a 4/5 star Monday. ‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è
Nice puzzle but ugh Democrats are not the left.

The entry at 5D (SEE YOU NEVER) reminded me of this classic New Yorker cartoon by its cartoon editor back when it was published (Bob Mankoff): - https://www.wusf.org/2014-03-24/new-yorker-cartoon-editor-explores-what-makes-us-get-it

A sprightly Monday puzzle.

Georgia's voting sticker (41A) is not red, white & blue, it's a peach.

Yet another Monday level puzzle ü§¨

If you go back to the first week of June of 1982, then you‚Äôd see  a *real* puzzle ü§¨

When will Shortz stop kowtowing to Big Crossword and publish crosswords that are not humanly solvable ü§¨

Oops! Pardon, today indeed is Monday puzzle. But enjoy the vignette of what the comment section has felt like recently ;-)
Hit a personal record at 5:05. I know there's probably a million other users who have achieved a faster time, but for me it was a special moment.

I really liked this one. Each theme answer felt unique from the others which I appreciated. 
Happy Monday, Crosslandia.
Had to think of the Krusty Krab when solving "Lobster Trap"
Hannah, perhaps celebrate the publication of your puzzle with some QUICHELORRAINE...
Another clever early week puzzle, thank you!
I rarely get emu-ed, but perhaps I should have said ‚ÄúI‚ÄôLL SEE YOU IN AITCH EE DOUBLE HOCKEY STICKS‚Äù to indicate what I wished for 5D

How about:

[Lead-in to "I shall not want"]

THELORDISMYSHEPHERD

(Clue and answer from a Newbie the night before a blizzard, maybe...)
I shouldn't have confidently entered CAREER for 34A.
Was it a coincidence that  U-S-A was followed immediately by U-S-B? I was really hoping the next answer would have been U-S-C. Another time perhaps.

Really wish all the people jumping in the comments to point out errors in the puzzle would take 5 seconds first to look up whether they are actually right.

Nonetheless, an enjoyable Monday, with a few smiles (lookin‚Äô at you THE LORAX and DELOREAN). Thanks Hannah!
New personal best of 2:40! I‚Äôll take it.

userLocation: Spring Hill, just south of Armageddon
commentBody: Any one else have the feeling that this week's Monday is trying in its own feisty way to apologize for last week?

The upstanding baker is my roll model.

(He just loafs what he does.)

Okay the Eric Clapton performance is great, but the true all-time-classic performance of While My Guitar Gently Weeps is in a different all-star tribute to George Harrison, at the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame, with an otherworldly Prince: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dWRCooFKk3c

Thinking about this theme and my mind went straight to JACOB ELORDI... same length as BACHELOR PAD and NAVEL ORANGE, albeit less fun! This was such a nice set of themed clues and a cute way to tie it all together. Fun quick Monday!
I think I‚Äôm going to start wearing a BERET.
Great puzzle to start the week! Simple, but clever. Here's hoping for some real challenges come Thursday!

Very nice. Achieved my goal of no look-ups for the second time and amazing time of 23 minutes (I thought I'd check just this once). 
Fortunately the crossers gave me OUTROS, ASADO, GRE, I VOTED and reminded me of the (to me) very odd BOOYAH. Which is how it should be.

Nice job, Hannah! It was good to see the great Alison Bechdel of D(y)kes To Watch Out For get a mention. Fitting the theme, Johnny Cash with Why Me Lord: https://youtu.be/H0jLHgjGoC0?si=PbiejP3aGxO48OD9

Lovely writeup, Natan.  In one short piece you wove in constructor insight, humor, beautiful turns of phrase, and references that complement the puzzle.  Written clearly and infused with personality.

Bravo, sir!
Loved it!

Liked everything about this one.

Lovely way to start the week.

Continued my streak of 236 Mondays in a row after having deliberately ended my 55 day streak yesterday. 

As a non native English speaker not living in the US it ended up taking too much of my time and was not fun anymore. Now I know at least that I can take on a crossword any day of the week should I have the time. 

(Probably will continue my Tuesday and Wednesday streak too)

Nice grid.  I let the reveal fill in from the crosses which was a nice punch line. Many thanks. 

Over 20" so far, heavy wet snow with significant drifting but the power has stayed on.

SEE YOU NEVER?

I prefer, "Smell you later....forever!"

Achieved my all-time personal best today with 3:30! Lovely puzzle, everything just fell into place and I got most of the across entries on the first run, which made the down entries very easy with so much already filled in.

One of those runs where I didn‚Äôt even notice the theme until after completion - I enjoyed the theme though once I saw it. 

As a Beatles zealot I knew the crossword gods were on my side early with the lovely George reference at 15A - WEEPS intersecting LSD was tasteful too, even if the boys had moved onto other sources of inspiration by 1968 (looking at you Maharishi).

Thanks Hannah for a great puzzle!

Two days ago, we had the answer MYSTERY BOX, and that‚Äôs a mighty good term for a blank grid.  Today‚Äôs mystery box brought me much pleasure:
‚Ä¢	Four theme answers with zing.
‚Ä¢	A revealer I tried to guess at after leaving it blank and not reading its clue.  I flunked, but loved the trying.
‚Ä¢	Images popped in my mind as I filled answers in.  I saw that EYELET, ANVIL, BABY BIB, and I VOTED sticker.  I even flashed on a spectacular spiral GALAXY.
‚Ä¢	I heard snippets from ‚ÄúWhile My Guitar Gently Weeps‚Äù, a song I love.
‚Ä¢	I smiled at the Boggle-style OWL (beginning with the O in BACHELOR) near WOODSY.
‚Ä¢	More smiles came from ANVIL dropping down the grid, and the cross of SUN and HEAT UP.

Your mystery box, Hannah, was a delight.  Thank you so much for making it!

This puzzle was WAY too easy. I can't believe that out of all-- wait. It's a Monday? Carry on. :)

(And well done!)
So nice to read so many positive comments for a change. I was about ready to quit reading the comments page,

For those of you looking for more of a challenge on this snowy morning in the Northeast, try this Brooke Husic gem from today's New Yorker: https://www.newyorker.com/puzzles-and-games-dept/crossword/2026/02/23

A nice Monday. 
But, NIGHTS? Really? 

Think the editors let that one slide

What a sweet Monday puzzle. Love the theme; simple enough for Monday but not too obvious. Nice fill, not much glue, what‚Äôs not to love?
My personal 5D is ‚Äòdon‚Äôt let the door hit you on the way out‚Äô, generally accompanied by a none emu friendly expletive. Don‚Äôt get on my bad side, I don‚Äôt play nice.

[Psychotherapist?]









ROLE REVERSAL ENGINEER

Puzzle filled in VERY quickly, so I had 37A's Reveal early on....but instead chose not to use the giant hint, which kind of kicked in the instant you saw an E...

I do not quite get 22A.  Is this a new usage or something.  I almost never watch a YouTube video unless it's Stephen Colbert or John Stewart...maybe even Jay Leno...with political commentary.  You know--a form of psychotherapy.

54D was the only new thing under the sun...  Nice start to the day!  Shortly I'll be off to the guild meeting:  Quilters, Ahoy!

BOOYAH! Absolutely destroyed my PB in less time it took to assemble a Mr. Potato Head. Took a break in between across and downs (let the timer run), made a 3-egg ham/cheese/onion and pepper omelet, and a batch of a dozen blueberry pancakes from scratch (ok, Bisquick helped).
Tomorrow's puzzle should be a doozy.

Today's the first of 4 days I can finally talk without sounding like Tone Loc, so this sinus/mucus/nasal curse is finally starting to lift. At least today, I sound more like Bea Arthur." Oh, South, where is thy Spring? O sea, where is thy peaceful breeze?" (1Cor 15, (for those of you still filled with yesterday's Holy Spirit)).

Enjoyable Monday puzzle. Pretty smooth solve and didn't tumble to the theme until I was almost done. That's always a nice touch. Puzzle find today - a Sunday from March 29, 1998 by Robert H. Wolfe with the title: "Two by thirteen." Pretty amazing feat of construction. Thirteen rebus squares in that one, each of them containing two consecutive letters of the alphabet. e.g. - AB CD EF GH.. etcetera. So - every letter of the alphabet was in one of the rebuses. Some answer examples: BO(YZ)NTHEHOOD (crossing) X(YZ)AFFAIR CHI(MN)EYSWEEP (crossing) LI(MN) NARRO(WX)ING (crossing) SHO(WX)RATEDFILMS LO(UV)RE crossing Y(OU)VE PE(OP)LE crossing H(OP)E A(CD)C crossing (CD)ROM Can't imagine what it would have taken to construct something like that. Here's the link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=3/29/1998&g=93&d=A ....
Excellent Monday, including a theme, thanks Hannah!

One more puzzle find. One of the strangest I've ever seen. A Sunday from April 4, 1993 by Tap Osborn with the title: "Title search." Some theme clue and answer examples: "ALEVEL" ALLABOUTEVE "ABARBESMS" BABESINARMS "USEOH" CRAZYHOUSE "ENUTROF" REVERSALOFFORTUNE "AVRETHS" RANDOMHARVEST "LALADAMPY" LADYWITHALAMP "WAOLNIDECRLANED" ALICEINWONDERLAND And there were more. Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=4/4/1993&g=31&d=D ...
Test
Clever theme! (Maybe it‚Äôs just me ) but I have never heard of OUTROS before. Thankfully it was my only option.

USA -> USB 

*chef's kiss*
That was so fast! It was a easy fun one after a while!
Good job Hannah ‚Äì I liked it.
Absolutely loved this crossword! Although it was a bit tough, I pushed through and finished in an impressive 17 minutes and 55 seconds. What a rush!
Hit a PR today! Great way to start the week :)

Just wanted to hop on here to share that after a little over 4 years of solving, I finally got my first Monday puzzle in under 4 minutes! Previously my closest call was 4:06, but this time I breezed through the puzzle in just 3:50 without even really hurrying. I know that solve times and streaks aren't the best way to measure enjoyment, but it's nice to hit a silly little goal I've been getting nearer and nearer to over the past year or so.

So thank you Hannah for this sweet Monday puzzle! Such a nicely flowing fill and a theme that I think has the perfect balance of being clever and not too obvious, while still being simple and easy to figure out, perfect for a Monday :-)

This was one of the easiest Monday crosswords that I have filled in. Normally I have to look at the answer key to figure out an answer. I spelled one entry wrong which threw me off for about 30 seconds. The bits of trivia were exciting to solve. Who knew that there is a Guinness record for assembling a Mr. Potato Head?! Overall this was an extremely fun crossword to do.

Thank you, Hannah, for a very fine Monday grid! I didn't best my RECORD, but it had just the right DEPTH for the start to the week. Natan, I also enjoyed your nice commentary comparing a puzzle to a constructor's personal mixtape -- Hannah's playlist was perfect and could have included The Mamas & the Papas chestnut, "Monday, Monday."üé∂

The 30 mph north wind is rattling the windows right now as I look out at our blizzard conditions. Stay safe & warm, northeast friends! ‚ùÑÔ∏èü´∂üèº‚ùÑÔ∏è
OUTROS was a new one for me, but I couldn't find any other solution so I decided it was legit. Overall, a nice puzzle, although I didn't get the theme until I checked the column.

I admit to not catching the ROLE REVERSAL in the theme answers. 

I did enjoy the USA vs USB  (Is that Canada after the Olympic Hockey? I jest)

Definitely a breezy fun Monday
I liked this!  Was a pretty jazzy Monday and loved seeing Alison Bechdel. Yay!
Not me confidently typing FREUDIAN SLIPS for the revealer clue...

This puzzle is like a piece of BODYHORROR (as seen a  couple days ago) for Mr. Potato Head. Sure, there‚Äôs the acute vertigo from having all your parts whirled around at high speed while some kid treats you like a Rubik‚Äôs Cube. But how about that new ANVIL piece grafted to your head? And a NAVELORANGE erupting from your abdomen like some sweet-and-starchy Alien?? And I can hear him now: ‚ÄúNo! No! Don‚Äôt thread a lace through my EYELET!!‚Äù  Not to mention the shame of all the NOS rejections.

But still, better than that guy going for the record of *slowest* assembly: ‚ÄúSEEYOUNEVER, Mr. P.‚Äù

I know a guy who is so dimwitted that even after noticing, and taking advantage of the fact, that LOR recurred in some of the long answers, he didn't notice that they all followed an E and in spite of 37A he had to read the column to discover what that was all about. I told him he should probably give up doing puzzles.

Please Google and then watch the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame video of several guitar greats playing My Guitar Gently Weeps for George Harrison‚Äôs induction. We saw this at the Museum as part of an AV history of the institution. All are great but Prince is transcendent. He had died recently and there was not a dry eye in the house.
Does anyone know why I solved the crossword, got a time, and then went back on the tab only to see my time is now apparently 11 hours?

One more puzzle find - the strangest I've ever encountered. Had to ponder for a bit looking at the filled in grid before I finally sort of caught on to what was going on. Anyway... here are the theme clues and answers: "Officious____" ACREATURWITHFINS "Armageddon____!" SICKANDTIREDOFITALL "Humus____" STOPSMOKINGSOMUCH "Universe___" PERSONIVETOLDTHISTO "Acoustic____" ISUSEDINBILLIARDS And there were a couple of others. Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=6/18/1989&g=68&d=A ....
ELOR!!!

I have questions:

1. Who composed the piano trio jingle we hear upon solving the puzzle?  Do they collect performance royalties every time someone solves?

2. What exactly does a puzzle editor do?  The constructor creates the puzzle and the clues, so what does the editor do?

3. In the Marcella Hazan ragu bolognese preparation, the milk precedes the white wine, but would it be okay to add the wine first, boil it out, then the nutmeg, and then the milk after?

Sad to say I thought I was going to start today with my first ever week-long streak but for some reason it didn't catch my Saturday solve! I don't know if I got it done too late in the day on Sunday for it to count or if it didn't register because I finished on my phone. Got Sunday done today in time to have a 2 day streak. I just don't have time for these weekend puzzles over the weekend!

Anyway, very fun Monday puzzle. Thought I'd get it in under five but the southeast corner threw me. One of my very few puzzles with no lookups and it was fun to see the theme come together. I'm getting better at this. :)

Okay - one more puzzle find. NEVER seen another one like this. Here are the three theme clues and answers: "What Satan gets from poison ivy?" THEWICKEDITCH "Money earned by a hospital worker?" INTERNREVENUE "Donation for crackpots?" DOLLARSTONUTS And then the 'reveal' - two paired answers: 22a -"With 45-across, book title with a hint to this puzzle's theme." WHERES And 45-across: "see 22-across" WALDO Think about it. Here's the link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=8/19/2004&g=20&d=A ....
27D stumped me because we call them POTS. I couldn't figure out what they were asking for!
FYI planets revolve around stars, so SUN is a little misleading! The sun is specific to our system. Similar to why the solar system is ours specifically and planetary systems describe other stars.

NAVEL ORANGE
POMEGRANATE 

Same number of letters, both fruits with belly buttons

(Offered up for a future puzzle theme)

My favorite encore clues from last week:

[Big name in London]  (3)
[Docs that deal with sensitive information]  (4)


BEN
NDAS

@Grumpy
LOL I guess I didn‚Äôt see that one, I must have solved with crosses. Agree there are other ways to clue ESE even on a Monday.
@Grumpy Still better than the "Direction from Nowheresville to Obscuretown" type clues...

@Al  in Pittsburgh
Why bother Andrzej?

@SP

I'd be a bit surprised if you've never heard of "Fun House", the musical based on ALISON Bechdel's graphic novel, or the interesting if simplistic Bechdel Test.

SP,
Not a new artist (at least to the crossword):

Thu Dec 19, 2019	
38A	
Alison ___, author of "Fun Home"	
Andy Kravis and Erik Agard	

Saw "Fun Home" on Broadway with the family.

2 results for FUNHOME from Modern Era puzzles:

Fri May 15, 2020	
36D	
2015 winner of Best Musical	
Christopher Adams	

Thu Aug 31, 2017	
70A	
Alison Bechdel memoir made into a hit 2015 Broadway musical	
Zachary Spitz	


1 result for FUNHOME from Variety puzzles:

Jun 16, 2019	
Diagramless	9A	
2015 musical based on an Alison Bechdel memoir	
Alex Eaton-Salners

@ad absurdum

I have heard of Fun Home, but don‚Äôt know who it was based on; and looking it up Obhave also heard of the Bechdel test but didn‚Äôt know the eponym. And I don‚Äôt mean new artist as in recent or unknown; just new to me

@SP

Oh yeah, I got that, but I thought as a musical lover you'd know it. I don't love the score on it's own, but I really enjoyed the show when I saw it. With Barry's family.

@Janis

The aglet is the plastic-coated end of a shoelace. The EYELET is the hole it goes through.

@Steve L

Yes, and it's not only shoes that have laces. You can have eyelets on a blouse, for example, to put a ribbon or other lace through.
Yes, Bruce, a lace could go through a grommet, but not in this puzzle, and, in any case, it's still not an aglet.

The trifecta of successively stacked comments here would be if Rich in Atlanta weighed in here. Further proof that Bruce, Barry Anaconda and Rich are the same person. Am I alone here?

Out of respect, I did wait, but the absence of the Rich persona debunked the myth. Or did it?

@Barry Ancona

Suppose one had a rope which was intended to pass through a relatively large grommet, maybe one on a tarp, and that the end of this rope had a plastic sheathing to prevent it from unraveling. Would that be referred to as an "aglet" or, given its size, simply an "agle"?

Bruce,
Is it faster to Chicago or by train?

@SBK
"I reject your reality and I substitute my own"
~The Dungeonmaster~
üòõ
@Edward Rice Isn't Mass short for Massachussetts?
@Edward Rice - As I understand it, Bostonians just call it "Mass Ave", and the rest of us call it Massachusetts Ave., pronounced Avenue.

@jennie

And you can get there off the Mass Pike.

@jennie-
Yes, I agree, having spent some time around there. It is just colloquially known as "Mass Ave."

@Paul:  "Isn't Mass short for Massachussetts?"

Exactly. So, the clue should have been "Mass. ____ (Boston thoroughfare)" with the period after the "Mass" indicating abbreviation in the clue. And, Jennie's right, that people "just call it," but in that case the clue should have included "colloquially" or something similar. "Boston thoroughfare, colloquially" would be right.

@Edward Rice
To me, the absence of a period in the shortened version is an indicator that it no longer needs an abbreviation cue in the clue. Cf., ATM and BLT recently discussed here after being clued without a shortness alert. If it's just plain "Mass Ave",  no need for 'shortly' or 'in brief'.

CLM,
Speaking of lobstah, 
I know it's a TRAP, 
but I've always called it a pot.
@Cat Lady Margaret It‚Äôs a very old term (I‚Äôm guessing 150-200 years at least) and people everywhere said a lot of things differently a long time ago.

CLM, You are not alone. "For decades, Edgar Comee, of Brunswick, Maine, waged a determined battle against use of the term "nor'easter" by the press, which usage he considered "a pretentious and altogether lamentable affectation" and "the odious, even loathsome, practice of landlubbers who would be seen as salty as the sea itself". His efforts, which included mailing hundreds of postcards, were profiled, just before his death in 2005 at the age of 88, in The New Yorker." https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Noreaster
@Barry Ancona Thanks. This is exactly the exchange to reset the forum.

@Cat Lady Margaret My husband, whose Maine roots go back for centuries, also hates this term!

(I am more of a mutt and wasn‚Äôt born in Maine, although both of my parents were and many of our ancestors. Hubby and I are even very distant cousins.)

@Cat Lady Margaret I don't think "Nor'Easter" is meant to imitate the New England dialect, but comes to us from the "sailor's dialect" which is a variant of the "pirate's dialect" which is a variant of "West Country English" dialect. Arrrgh, matey! For the best parody of this dialect, check out the Sea Captain (Horatio McCallister) from the Simpsons. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-FfhlAYlLFI

Thanks for the replies, pals. I knew I could count on you!

‚ÄúJust right for a Monday‚Äù, heh.
@Cat Lady Margaret Had me a sweet lobstah roll up thatawawy a bunch of years ago. Best sammich evah!

@Cat Lady Margaret - You are correct. I consider "Nor'Easter" to be a twee affectation usually employed by urbanites trying to sound rusticated. 

The real old timers say "Nawtheastah" - my preferred spelling, but your ‚ÄúNo‚Äôth Eastah‚Äù is also correct. 

I will now go dig out my copy of the excellent book "Northeaster" and copy down the explanation of why the author (a Mainer) refused to name it "Nor'Easter..." 

Back in a bit...

@Barry Ancona - I wish I had seen your response sooner -- I just responded to the OP saying I would return when I dug up the book "Northeaster" and typed in the one-page explanation of why the title is not "Nor'Easter." I just did that, and the gist of the argument is based upon Comee's writings -- and I had no idea the Wikipedia entry included that!

@Barry Ancona - Up here in lobstah land, we call them "TRAPS" but I know that down in the southern fringes of the lobster range they are often referred to as "pots"

In New England you'd better use the correct term, although I know that in Connecticut they say "pot" -- but you New Yawkas have more or less assimilated Connecticut, at least culturally, right?

@HeathieJ

Don't you just hate it when children's books accurately predict the future?

@Anita
Baby steps, Anita, baby steps. Our voices are being heard. Power to the people!
@Mehitabel when the right moves far then what was right becomes the center and what was center becomes the left.

@Mehitabel
That's what I thought, but I suppose it's relative.

@ŒôŒ±œÉœâŒΩ  That is exactly the right's strategy, and it unfortunately works, for reasons i won't enumerate here. Leftists, for all our flaws, try to resist all that and hold the line on civil rights, a govt that serves the people, and a fair economy.

@Mehitabel

[insert crying emoji]
@Mehitabel hopefully we‚Äôll get a ‚ÄúRepublicans and fascists‚Äù clue next. Seems only fair.
@RichardZ: same!! Do you use that line on your friends, as I do?

@RichardZ That cartoon is hilarious!  I'm going to try that line the next time my wife asks me just WHEN am I going to finally get around to doing some unpleasant chore I've ignored for too long.  I wonder if her eyes will be laughing WITH me, or throwing daggers AT me?

@RichardZ This one has always been up there with the classics. A favorite of mine (having nothing to do with this puzzle) is one of Barsotti's puppy cartoons. An auctioneer is high on a podium and at the bottom is a little puppy. The caption: "The bidding will start at eleven million dollars." I love Barsotti! https://www.cartoonstock.com/cartoonists/charlesbarsotti?srsltid=AfmBOoq32AGa4bGDrvn_tjo6I-1CtQdRHD38RUL53eTqDnDTocT1NVZZ
One of my favorite cartoons of all time!

@Nancy I too use this all the time. But the cartoon of our new age remains this one: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/On_the_Internet,_nobody_knows_you%27re_a_dog Its memehood is so deep that it has been the subject of a documentary, as well as essays, videos, and animations.
@RichardZ I sent that to an ex when he asked my if we could have lunch.

@RichardZ

Not a computer in sight, a corded phone, and a suit pocket planner.  Those were the days, my friend, those were the days.

@Linda Jo 

Not sure if I'd go that far. It gets the job done, though.

@Linda Jo

But neither does it say I VOTED.

Here's the back story to the Ga voting sticker. Ya see, Big Watercraft had  to launch a campaign here regarding keeping one's bass boat properly moored to their dock. It did help eliminate the number of bass boats running amok in the fishing coves.

Meanwhile, as nepotism runs in the South, the word had to git out for us'uns to vote. Under mounting pressure from Big Vote, Big Watercraft's brother-in-law, Big Sticker repurposed the popular "I Secured My Boat" sticker to become "I Secured My Vote."

@Mishlev

I think we've found an heir of Johnathon Swift!

I just can not stop laughing. 

In spite of the fact I fear that this argument is tearing the forum apart, and my heart as well.  I personally feel in the odd position of one whose opinion on the matter has drifted considerably in the last six months or so (I think--I'm old, don't rely too much on me.)

Anyway, I love the way you've turned the controversy into Humor Undeniable.

Seriously, you might want to find an agent.

MOL. 22A has only been around (in print anyway) since 1967. https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/outro

@Mean Old Lady

Roughly 150 years ago, when I was a radio disk jockey, we'd note the intro and outro times of the songs we aired.  If the intro -- the instrumental before the lyrics began -- was 14 seconds, we'd have that much time to say incredibly witty things and not tred atop the singer.  The outro was also important, as if it was a fade, we could cut the song short and start the commercial break early.  Timing was everything.
